factoid: A soldier on a march is hemmed in and borne along by his regiment.
A sailor is hemmed in and borne along by his ship.
The soldier is surrounded by the same comrades as the sailor is surrounded by the same decks, masts, and rigging of his ship.
The soldier has around him the same comrades.
The soldier has around him the same ranks.
The soldier has around him the same sergeant major Iván Mítrich.
The soldier has around him the same company dog Jack.
The soldier has around him the same commanders.
The sailor rarely cares to know the latitude in which his ship is sailing.
On the day of battle, a stern note sounded in the moral atmosphere of an army.
The stern note announced the approach of something decisive and solemn.
The stern note awakened an unusual curiosity in the men.
On the day of battle, soldiers excitedly tried to get beyond the interests of their regiment.
On the day of battle, soldiers listened intently.
On the day of battle, soldiers looked about.
On the day of battle, soldiers eagerly asked concerning what was going on around them.
The fog had grown so dense that soldiers could not see ten paces ahead.
In the dense fog, bushes looked like gigantic trees.
In the dense fog, level ground looked like cliffs and slopes.
In the dense fog, an enemy could be invisible ten paces off.
The columns advanced for a long time in the same fog.
The columns descended and ascended hills.
The columns avoided gardens and enclosures.
The columns went over new and unknown ground.
The columns never encountered the enemy.
Soldiers became aware that other Russian columns were moving in the same direction.
Every soldier felt glad to know that many of our men were going to the same unknown place.
Soldiers said that the Kúrskies had gone past.
Soldiers said that many of our troops had gathered.
One soldier said that last night he looked at campfires and there was no end of them.
One soldier said that the campfires were a regular Moscow.
None of the column commanders rode up to the ranks or talked to the men.
The column commanders were out of humor and dissatisfied with the affair.
The column commanders merely carried out orders.
The troops marched gaily as they always did when going into action, especially to an attack.
After about an hour in the dense fog, the greater part of the men had to halt.
An unpleasant consciousness of some dislocation and blunder spread through the ranks.
The consciousness of dislocation and blunder was communicated rapidly, imperceptibly, and irrepressibly, like water in a creek.
If the Russian army had been alone without allies, the consciousness of mismanagement might have taken a long time to become a general conviction.
As it was, the disorder was attributed to the stupid Germans.
Everyone was convinced that a dangerous muddle had been occasioned by the sausage eaters.
A soldier asked why they had stopped.
A soldier asked if the way was blocked.
A soldier asked if they had already come up against the French.
A soldier replied that they could not hear the French.
A soldier replied that the French would be firing if they had.
A soldier said that the Germans had started them.
A soldier said that they now stood in the middle of a field without rhyme or reason.
A soldier said that it was all those damned Germans’ muddling.
A soldier called the Germans “stupid devils.”
A soldier said that he would send them in front.
A soldier said that they were crowding up behind.
A soldier said that they were hungry.
An officer said that they would soon be clear.
An officer said that the cavalry were blocking the way.
Another soldier said that the Germans didn’t know their own country.
An adjutant shouted what division they were.
The adjutant answered that they were the Eighteenth.
Another soldier said why they were here.
Another soldier said they should have gone on long ago.
Another soldier said they would not get there till evening.
An officer said the orders were stupid.
An officer said they didn’t know what they were doing.
A general rode past shouting angrily in a language other than Russian.
A soldier mimicked the general and said he would shoot the scoundrels.
Soldiers said they were ordered to be at the place before nine.
Soldiers said they had not gotten halfway.
Soldiers repeated that the orders were fine.
The feeling of energy with which the troops had started turned into vexation and anger at the stupid arrangements.
The feeling of energy turned into vexation and anger at the Germans.
